Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 05:12PM - edited Apr 13, 2012 02:42PM by Denise2730 I've been taking Ativan (aka Lorazepam) since 1998! I started with .5 mg. and lately I have been taking 3 mg. every night. I sleep better and wake up a little more refreshed but it's killing my memory. Since I've been taking it for so long I would have to be detoxed to get off of it but there are days when I'm so thankful I have it, not just for sleeping but for those occasional panic attacks I get when all this becomes a little too real.

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2011 01:50PM Denise2730 wrote: They all need to watch the movie "The Doctor". It's about one of these callous, insensitive doctors who develops cancer.  Very eye opening experience for him. Certainly changed his attitude right quick. Sorry that some of you beautiful ladies are having to deal with this. My oncologist told me if my breast cancer came back IT WOULD BE FATAL. WTF is up with that? I went in to his office thinking it was just a routine exam after my BMX and that I was home free. Now we're talking chemo, hormone treatment, etc. I just to want to throttle some of them.

Wish I was closer.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 09:34AM - edited Sep 20, 2011 09:35AM by Denise2730 << My oncologist told me if my breast cancer came back IT WOULD BE FATAL. WTF is up with that?<< Ummmm... what part of that don't you understand? Mine has come back. Mine is fatal. Sorry to be blunt, but maybe this isn't the forum for you. *susan* Why wouldn't this be the forum for me?  People have recurrences of breast cancer and it's not an automatic death sentence for every patient and I feel that a doctor telling me it will be is insensitive. I felt like he is pushing his agenda because that's how he makes his money. Imagine if everybody refused chemo, radiation, etc. What would the oncologists do?  I'm sorry to hear yours has come back. I'm fortunate that we live in a free country and I can choose how much, if any, treatment I want for myself.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 10:51PM Denise2730 wrote: Mine didn't hurt - I had 2 different kinds on the same day; the stereotactic & the mammogram guided biopsy. The only uncomfortable thing was the position you stay in for the one where you are on your stomach. I was actually falling asleep for the 2nd one (don't remember which one was which) and they kept waking me up asking if I was okay. You will be numbed up pretty good during the procedure. On a scale of 1-10 it was barely a 1 for me. Good luck and let us know. Denise

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 04:36PM Denise2730 wrote: Even though I'm only lla the quote that expresses my feelings best is this: "surviving early stage cancer is like crossing the Mafia and getting away with it - you may live but you will forever be looking over your shoulder". That's how I feel. I had a DMX only. Turned down chemo, rads & hormone blockers. Oncotype score was 9. So how come whenever I have a pain in my hip or a sudden cough does my mind immediately go to "mets"? Maybe years from now the fear will go away but it's still too new for me. I'm not sure I will ever feel whole again and I don't mean just physically.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 12:52PM Denise2730 wrote: You are on steroids???  Short story - I had to have steroids for my plantar fasciitis. I am a commited animal lover, so much that at one time I had 7 Chihuahuas and 4 cats. One day during steroid treatment, my cat killed a baby bird outside my front door that I was trying to save. I went after him with a metal meat tenderizer with the full intention of cracking his skull open! When I couldn't make contact with him because he ran in the house and started hiding I started throwing the mallet at him!  I was a crazy woman. Hence I will never take steroids again. But if you have to take them, remember that they can cause aggression & bitchiness.

Posts.Title: SEX - Very Raw Post cancerkicker Moderators

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2011 02:52PM Denise2730 wrote: YaYa - My sons who are 24 & 26 are pretty much the same way. I think it's denial in their case. Their father died in August of 2010 of lung cancer after what seemed like a very long 3 year battle. They are afraid of being orphans even though they are adults. I guess if they don't discuss it, it isn't happening. My oldest was in the hospital when I awoke from surgery and stayed with me for hours. Now I rarely hear from him. Yes, he's working full time and going to college so I cut him some slack. I know if I asked him for something he would do his best. My youngest "couldn't handle it" so only visited me in the hospital for about 10 minutes. My sister was there in the hospital and came here with a meal the day after I came home but I rarely hear from her now and she lives 30 minutes away. The only time I hear from her now is when she invites me to go out somewhere with her. LOL - that's really what I feel like doing right now. Thankfully I am living with my mother for awhile so I'm not alone. Until I got BC I truly didn't understand what a person with cancer needs. Your family is probably coming from a place of fear, denial and misunderstanding. That's why I'm glad we have this place to come to.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 06:45PM Denise2730 wrote: Peppopat - My onco score was 9 and my Onc was still trying to push chemo on me. When I said no, he wanted me to do radiation although I already had a DMX with one positive node (which means I normally wouldn't be a candidate for the oncotype DX test) but Dr. Doom knew I was dead set against chemo unless my score came back very high. Like you I'm turning down any further treatment at this point. I'm ordering a natural pill that removes all synthetic hormones from the body, changing my diet and I'm going back to the gym. Hey, it may work for me, it may not. Only time will tell. Denise
Posts.Title: I think Oncotype DX is a SCAM!! peppopat mysticalcity

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2012 12:57PM - edited Feb 9, 2012 12:57PM by Denise2730 Maybe it's just me because my husband was a wonderful lover but after 10 years sex wasn't a priority for me nobody how good it used to be. We had 2 small children, lots of financial problems, etc. and I just couldn't muster up the desire. Many men seem to think they just have to tell you they are in the mood and that's all we need to get aroused. After awhile sex became one more chore on my "to do list" and as we were having sex, I was making mental notes of all I had to do the next day between my job and my boy's schoolwork. Sex seems to stay great for men no matter how many years they are married. Sometimes I envy them that. But now I don't have to please anybody when I'm not in the mood. Perhaps it's selfish but worrying about pleasing someone else sexually right now would annoy the hell out of me. Denise
